_metadata.context: Integrated Framework for Inquiry and Creation

concepts.name: A/B Testing
concepts.theory_application: Compare two versions of a variable to determine which performs better against a defined metric.

variations.theory: Definition: A/B testing is running two simultaneous experimental arms. Procedural Link: The action is to run two simultaneous experimental arms to compare the efficacy of a treatment or variable.

Definition: A/B testing is comparing two versions to measure performance. Procedural Link: The action is to compare two versions (A and B) to objectively measure which performs better on a Key Performance Indicator (KPI). (N185)

Definition: A/B testing is comparing two versions of an argument. Procedural Link: The action is to compare two versions of an argument (e.g., in a brief survey) to measure which is more rhetorically persuasive to a target audience.
Definition: A/B testing is showing two design variants to users. Procedural Link: The action is to show two design variants to users to measure which is more intuitive or aesthetically preferred.

variations.expert: Responsible Research and Innovation (RRI) - The Ethicist
variations.theory: Definition: A/B testing is testing ethical compliance. Procedural Link: The action is to test the ethical compliance of two different system designs (A/B) to measure which minimizes data leakage or bias.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of A/B Testing. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Compare two versions of a variable to determine which performs better against a defined metric.
Definition: The universal structural principle of A/B Testing. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Compare two versions of a variable to determine which performs better against a defined metric.

concepts.name: Analysis
concepts.theory_application: Break down complex data or information into its constituent parts to understand its structure and relationships.

variations.theory: Definition: Analysis is applying statistical methods to raw data. Procedural Link: The action is to apply statistical methods to raw data to test the hypothesis and quantify uncertainty. (N33)

Definition: Analysis is finding the root cause of failure. Procedural Link: The action is to analyze user testing results, error logs, and performance metrics to find the root cause of feature failure.
Definition: Analysis is interpreting textual data. Procedural Link: The action is to interpret textual data, thematic codes, or qualitative interview transcripts to validate the initial claim.
Definition: Analysis is applying formal aesthetic theory. Procedural Link: The action is to apply formal aesthetic theory to critique the composition, form, or color choices in the work.
Definition: Analysis is diagnosing the root cause of friction. Procedural Link: The action is to use a structured framework to diagnose the root cause of process friction or a moral failure.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Analysis. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Break down complex data or information into its constituent parts to understand its structure and relationships.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Analysis. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Break down complex data or information into its constituent parts to understand its structure and relationships.

concepts.name: Calibration
concepts.theory_application: Adjust a system or instrument to ensure accuracy and alignment with a standard.

variations.theory: Definition: Calibration is adjusting equipment against a known standard. Procedural Link: The action is to adjust laboratory equipment or data models to ensure accuracy against a known standard.

Definition: Calibration is adjusting parameters based on testing. Procedural Link: The action is to adjust a product's parameters (e.g., algorithm weights, UI defaults) based on user testing to align with the success criteria.
Definition: Calibration is adjusting rhetoric to align with standards. Procedural Link: The action is to adjust the argumentative rhetoric or evidence base to align with expert peer review standards.

Definition: Calibration is adjusting the aesthetic compass. Procedural Link: The action is to adjust the internal aesthetic compass based on feedback to ensure the work's impact matches the artist's intent.
Definition: Calibration is adjusting moral intuition based on review. Procedural Link: The action is to adjust one’s own moral intuition or perspective based on a communal ethical review.
Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Calibration. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Adjust a system or instrument to ensure accuracy and alignment with a standard.
Definition: The universal structural principle of Calibration. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Adjust a system or instrument to ensure accuracy and alignment with a standard.

concepts.name: Correction
concepts.theory_application: Identify and rectify errors or deviations from the intended plan or standard.

variations.theory: Definition: Correction is implementing the final fix. Procedural Link: The action is to implement the final fix for a bug, a flawed procedure, or an error in the data processing pipeline.
Definition: Correction is implementing bug fixes. Procedural Link: The action is to implement bug fixes or usability improvements identified during testing and review.
Definition: Correction is rewriting and removing extraneous prose. Procedural Link: The action is to write a revised section, incorporate a counterargument, or remove extraneous prose.
Definition: Correction is physical work of revision. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the physical work of re-sculpting, re-rendering, or revising the composition of the artwork.
Definition: Correction is implementing systemic change. Procedural Link: The action is to implement a systemic change to governance or procedure to address a diagnosed problem.
Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Correction. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Identify and rectify errors or deviations from the intended plan or standard.
Definition: The universal structural principle of Correction. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Identify and rectify errors or deviations from the intended plan or standard.

concepts.name: Critique
concepts.theory_application: Subject work to critical analysis and feedback to identify strengths, weaknesses, and areas for improvement.

variations.theory: Definition: Critique is rigorous, adversarial challenge. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the social process of scientific peer review, where the manuscript is submitted to experts for rigorous, adversarial challenge.

Definition: Critique is structured, actionable feedback. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a structured design review or code review session where peers offer detailed, actionable feedback on a work-in-progress. (N34)

Definition: Critique is constructive feedback. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the formal process of peer review or a writing workshop where scholars offer constructive feedback on argument structure and evidence. (N34)

Definition: Critique is intellectual and aesthetic evaluation. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the core pedagogical process in art and design schools, where the work is formally presented for intellectual and aesthetic evaluation. (N34)

Definition: Critique is structured group reflection. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a structured group reflection or facilitated dialogue used to process feedback on performance or behavior.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Critique. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Subject work to critical analysis and feedback to identify strengths, weaknesses, and areas for improvement.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Critique. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Subject work to critical analysis and feedback to identify strengths, weaknesses, and areas for improvement.

concepts.name: Cultivation
concepts.theory_application: Nurture and develop skills, qualities, or systems over time through consistent attention and effort.

variations.theory: Definition: Cultivation is nurturing scientific rigor. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the long-term effort to nurture scientific rigor, intellectual honesty, and transparency in methodology.
Definition: Cultivation is nurturing user satisfaction and morale. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the active nurturing of user satisfaction, team morale, and system resilience.

Definition: Cultivation is improving complexity and nuance. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the commitment to continuously improve the complexity and nuance of the argument through iterative effort.
Definition: Cultivation is nurturing craft mastery. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the ongoing nurturing and refinement of craft mastery through deliberate practice and focused iteration.
Definition: Cultivation is nurturing communal harmony. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the active nurturing of communal harmony and ethical self-awareness.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Cultivation. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Nurture and develop skills, qualities, or systems over time through consistent attention and effort.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Cultivation. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Nurture and develop skills, qualities, or systems over time through consistent attention and effort.

concepts.name: Debugging
concepts.theory_application: Systematically identify, isolate, and correct errors or defects in a system or process.

variations.theory: Definition: Debugging is systematic error removal. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the systematic, technical process of identifying and removing errors from experimental setups or computational models. (N200)

Definition: Debugging is finding the root cause of failure. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the core of technical refinement; identifying and removing code errors, logic flaws, or security vulnerabilities in software.

Definition: Debugging is correcting logical flaws. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the intellectual process of identifying and correcting logical fallacies, unsupported warrants, or unclear prose.
Definition: Debugging is correcting technical flaws. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the technical work of correcting flawed joints, corrupted files, or inaccurate color schemes.

variations.expert: Responsible Research and Innovation (RRI) - The User
variations.theory: Definition: Debugging is removing biases. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the effort to identify and remove biases or flawed assumptions within a decision-making protocol.
Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Debugging. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Systematically identify, isolate, and correct errors or defects in a system or process.
Definition: The universal structural principle of Debugging. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Systematically identify, isolate, and correct errors or defects in a system or process.

concepts.name: Non-defensive listening
concepts.theory_application: Listen with full attention and empathy, suspending judgment to truly understand the speaker's perspective and underlying needs.

variations.theory: Definition: Deep listening is processing feedback without defense. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the discipline of actively processing feedback from peers or data, explicitly suppressing the instinct to defend one’s work. (N92)

Definition: Deep listening is processing raw user complaints. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the discipline of actively processing raw user complaints and qualitative feedback, listening for the unspoken problem behind the requested solution.

Definition: Deep listening is reading critique with humility. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the discipline of reading a peer's critique or a counterargument with humility and full attention.

Definition: Deep listening is receiving critique as objective data. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the discipline of receiving critique without defending the work, allowing the feedback to be processed as objective data.

Definition: Deep listening is non-judgmental reception. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the non-judgmental reception of input from a community, particularly when the feedback is emotionally charged or critical. (N92)

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Non-defensive listening. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Listen with full attention and empathy, suspending judgment to truly understand the speaker's perspective and underlying needs.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Non-defensive listening. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Listen with full attention and empathy, suspending judgment to truly understand the speaker's perspective and underlying needs.

concepts.name: Diagnosing
concepts.theory_application: Systematically investigate symptoms to identify the underlying cause of a problem or condition.

variations.theory: Definition: Diagnosing is determining if effects are real signals. Procedural Link: The action is to apply statistical tests to data to determine if observed effects are real signals or random noise.

Definition: Diagnosing is performing Root Cause Analysis (RCA). Procedural Link: The action is to perform Root Cause Analysis (RCA) to determine the deepest process failure that led to a bug or user frustration.
Definition: Diagnosing is analyzing argument structure. Procedural Link: The action is to analyze the structure of an argument for logical fallacies or unsupported claims.

Definition: Diagnosing is analyzing work against aesthetic principles. Procedural Link: The action is to analyze the work against aesthetic principles to identify the precise source of formal imbalance or narrative failure.
Definition: Diagnosing is using a structured framework. Procedural Link: The action is to use a structured framework to diagnose the root cause of process friction or a moral failure.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Diagnosing. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Systematically investigate symptoms to identify the underlying cause of a problem or condition.
Definition: The universal structural principle of Diagnosing. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Systematically investigate symptoms to identify the underlying cause of a problem or condition.

concepts.name: Discipline
concepts.theory_application: Maintain rigorous standards and consistent effort in the execution of tasks, even when difficult or tedious.

variations.theory: Definition: Discipline is the rigor required to follow the revision plan. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the rigor required to follow the revision plan, even when it means challenging deeply held hypotheses or cutting favored data.

Definition: Discipline is the consistent application of quality assurance. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the consistent application of quality assurance processes and clear standards (Definition of Done).

Definition: Discipline is systematic intellectual rigor. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the systematic intellectual rigor required to engage with opposing arguments (Steelmanning) and perform tedious line-editing.

Definition: Discipline is sustained self-control. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the sustained self-control needed to engage in iterative refinement rather than abandoning the project after the initial creative rush.
Definition: Discipline is moral fortitude. Procedural Link: The action is to focus on the moral fortitude required to enforce ethical principles when they conflict with convenience or speed.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Discipline. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Maintain rigorous standards and consistent effort in the execution of tasks, even when difficult or tedious.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Discipline. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Maintain rigorous standards and consistent effort in the execution of tasks, even when difficult or tedious.

concepts.name: Feedback
concepts.theory_application: Provide and receive constructive information about performance or behavior to guide improvement.

variations.theory: Definition: Merton defined 'Organized Skepticism' as a core norm of science. Procedural Link: The action is to treat formal peer reviewer comments as objective data to be analyzed, not as personal attacks, to maintain intellectual honesty.

Definition: The goal of the 'Measure' phase is to achieve validated learning. Procedural Link: The action is to prioritize 'validated learning' (data that proves or disproves a hypothesis) over mere opinion or feature requests.

Definition: The CRP is a structured method for giving constructive feedback. Procedural Link: The action is to use a structured protocol to ensure feedback is specific, actionable, and focused on the work, not the person.

Definition: The CRP gives the artist agency over the critique process. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure the artist must set the terms of the critique (Frame the Question - N95), giving them agency over the feedback they receive.

Definition: Habermas defined 'communicative rationality'—agreement reached through reasoned dialogue. Procedural Link: The action is to ensure feedback is received through a dialogic process that is free of coercion and power imbalances.
Definition: Visible Learning. Procedural Link: Provide 'Just-in-Time' feedback that answers: Where am I going? How am I going? Where to next?
Definition: The universal structural principle of Feedback. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Provide and receive constructive information about performance or behavior to guide improvement.

concepts.name: Insight
concepts.theory_application: Achieve a sudden, deep understanding of a complex problem or situation, often involving a shift in perspective.

variations.theory: Definition: The 'Aha!' moment is associated with a burst of gamma activity in the brain. Procedural Link: The action is to recognize the moment of insight as the 'Aha!' moment that reveals the root cause of an error or the unexpected meaning of a scientific finding.

Definition: The insight is the 'unmet need' that, if solved, unlocks a major market opportunity. Procedural Link: The action is to recognize the insight as the 'unmet need' that, if solved, unlocks a major market opportunity.

Definition: Barthes analyzed how cultural artifacts function as 'myths' (ideological narratives). Procedural Link: The action is to recognize the insight as the 'myth'—the hidden ideological function of a seemingly innocent cultural artifact.

Definition: The insight is the 'felt sense' that the emerging idea perfectly balances challenge and skill. Procedural Link: The action is to recognize the insight as the 'felt sense' that the emerging idea perfectly balances challenge and skill, signaling the potential for flow.

Definition: Meadows focuses on identifying leverage points. Procedural Link: The action is to recognize the insight as the 'leverage point'—the small change in the system that yields a large, positive outcome.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Insight. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Achieve a sudden, deep understanding of a complex problem or situation, often involving a shift in perspective.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Insight. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Achieve a sudden, deep understanding of a complex problem or situation, often involving a shift in perspective.

concepts.name: Iteration
concepts.theory_application: Repeat a process with the aim of approaching a desired goal, target, or result, making improvements in each cycle.

variations.theory: Definition: Iteration is the looping of the cycle. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the looping of the cycle: revise the protocol, run the next experiment, analyze, and revise the protocol again.

Definition: Iteration is the rapid cycle of build-measure-learn-fix. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the rapid cycle of build-measure-learn-fix, continuously improving the product over a series of short cycles.

Definition: Iteration is the continuous cycle of revising the draft. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the continuous cycle of revising the draft, seeking feedback, and incorporating changes.
Definition: Iteration is the repeated generation of variations. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the repeated generation of variations on a theme to test and refine the aesthetic concept.
Definition: Iteration is the continual cycle of reflection-in-action. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the continual cycle of reflection-in-action to refine process and conduct.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Iteration. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Repeat a process with the aim of approaching a desired goal, target, or result, making improvements in each cycle.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Iteration. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Repeat a process with the aim of approaching a desired goal, target, or result, making improvements in each cycle.

concepts.name: Mastery
concepts.theory_application: Achieve a high level of skill or command over a subject or activity through sustained practice and refinement.

variations.theory: Definition: Mastery is the complete command of technique. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the complete command of experimental technique and analytical precision.

Definition: Mastery is the seamless, highly efficient execution of processes. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the seamless, highly efficient execution of the product development and quality assurance processes.
Definition: Mastery is the advanced ability to construct arguments. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the advanced ability to construct flawless, highly persuasive, and defensible arguments.
Definition: Mastery is the highest level of control over material. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the highest level of control over material, form, and expressive intent.
variations.rubric: Aim for highest level of control.

variations.theory: Definition: Mastery is the ultimate self-regulation. Procedural Link: The action is to aim for the ultimate self-regulation (Tool 10) and consistency of ethical conduct.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Mastery. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Achieve a high level of skill or command over a subject or activity through sustained practice and refinement.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Mastery. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Achieve a high level of skill or command over a subject or activity through sustained practice and refinement.

concepts.name: Peer Review
concepts.theory_application: Subject work to the scrutiny of others in the same field to ensure quality, validity, and adherence to standards.

variations.theory: Definition: Merton defined 'Organized Skepticism' as a core norm of science. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the foundational process of validation where anonymous experts challenge the methodology and conclusions. (N38)

Definition: Peer review is a core practice of cross-functional collaboration. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the system where developers examine a colleague's code and technical design before it is merged into the main codebase.

Definition: Habermas defined 'communicative rationality'—agreement reached through reasoned dialogue. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the system where scholars submit their manuscripts to journal reviewers for critique of rigor and significance.

Definition: The CRP is a structured method for giving constructive feedback. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the formal process where fellow artists or designers evaluate a work against shared standards of craft and concept.

Definition: Wilson advocates for research as a relational act. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a structured working group where peers examine each other’s ethical dilemmas and decision-making processes.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Peer Review. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Subject work to the scrutiny of others in the same field to ensure quality, validity, and adherence to standards.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Peer Review. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Subject work to the scrutiny of others in the same field to ensure quality, validity, and adherence to standards.

concepts.name: Prune for Focus
concepts.theory_application: Deliberately remove elements, features, or data that do not contribute to the core purpose, enhancing clarity and efficiency.

variations.theory: Definition: Pruning is eliminating irrelevant data. Procedural Link: The action is to eliminate interesting but irrelevant experiments or data to focus the research on the core hypothesis.

Definition: Pruning is 'killing your darlings.' Procedural Link: The action is to engage in 'Killing your darlings': ruthlessly cutting a clever feature that does not serve the core user value or the sprint goal.
Definition: Pruning is cutting extraneous prose. Procedural Link: The action is to cut extraneous prose, tangential arguments, or unnecessary archival evidence to sharpen the focus of the thesis.

Definition: Pruning is intentional removal to strengthen the remaining elements. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the intentional removal of an element from a composition to strengthen the remaining elements. (N59)

Definition: Pruning is cutting a project that diverts resources. Procedural Link: The action is to make the difficult decision to cut a project that, while well-intentioned, diverts resources from the core ethical mission.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Prune for Focus. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Deliberately remove elements, features, or data that do not contribute to the core purpose, enhancing clarity and efficiency.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Prune for Focus. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Deliberately remove elements, features, or data that do not contribute to the core purpose, enhancing clarity and efficiency.

concepts.name: Purging
concepts.theory_application: Remove unnecessary, obsolete, or harmful elements to restore order and efficiency.

variations.theory: Definition: Purging is removing unnecessary complexity. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the deliberate and sometimes painful removal of unnecessary complexity, bad data, or technical debt from the process.
Definition: Purging is removing low-value features. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the removal of low-value, high-maintenance features or obsolete code from the product.
Definition: Purging is eliminating extraneous words. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the ruthless elimination of extraneous words, logical flaws, or self-serving arguments.

Definition: Purging is the destruction of a failed iteration. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the dramatic removal of a visual element or the destruction of a failed iteration to free up creative space.
Definition: Purging is the deliberate removal of bureaucracy. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the deliberate removal of an unnecessary rule or bureaucracy that impedes ethical action.
Guided Continuous Improvement (GCI). Procedural Link: Use data to identify the problem, select a solution, and verify the result in a loop.
Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Purging. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Remove unnecessary, obsolete, or harmful elements to restore order and efficiency.
Definition: The universal structural principle of Purging. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Remove unnecessary, obsolete, or harmful elements to restore order and efficiency.

concepts.name: QA Testing
concepts.theory_application: Systematically verify that a product or system meets specified requirements and standards.

variations.theory: Definition: QA testing is systematic quality assurance. Procedural Link: The action is to perform systematic quality assurance checks to ensure the experimental data acquisition system is functioning according to specification.

Definition: QA testing is the technical, scripted process of testing software. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the technical, scripted process of testing the software against acceptance criteria and technical specifications. (N35)
Definition: QA testing is rigorous fact-checking. Procedural Link: The action is to perform rigorous fact-checking, citation review, and logical audits of the paper before publication.
Definition: QA testing is technical checks on material durability. Procedural Link: The action is to perform technical checks on material durability, digital file integrity, or structural stability.

variations.expert: Responsible Research and Innovation (RRI) - The PO
variations.theory: Definition: QA testing is auditing compliance against standards. Procedural Link: The action is to audit the compliance of a product or process against predefined ethical standards.
Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of QA Testing. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Systematically verify that a product or system meets specified requirements and standards.
Definition: The universal structural principle of QA Testing. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Systematically verify that a product or system meets specified requirements and standards.

concepts.name: Refinement
concepts.theory_application: Make small changes to improve a process, product, or idea based on feedback and analysis.

variations.theory: Definition: Refinement is improving the research methodology. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the act of improving the research methodology, apparatus, or analytical model based on the initial findings.
Definition: Refinement is continuous improvement based on feedback. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the continuous improvement of the product based on feedback and measurement.
Definition: Refinement is the iteration and improvement of the argument. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the iteration and improvement of the argument, evidence, and prose.

Definition: Refinement is the iterative process of moving a work to a finished state. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the iterative process of moving a piece of work from a prototype to a finished state.
Definition: Refinement is the continuous improvement of relational processes. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the continuous improvement of relational processes and self-awareness.
Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Refinement. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Make small changes to improve a process, product, or idea based on feedback and analysis.
Definition: The universal structural principle of Refinement. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Make small changes to improve a process, product, or idea based on feedback and analysis.

concepts.name: Retrospective
concepts.theory_application: Look back on a past event or period to evaluate what went well, what didn't, and how to improve in the future.

variations.theory: Definition: Retrospective is analyzing the process of the experiment. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a meeting to analyze the process of the experiment, identifying flaws in the protocol or teamwork that should be fixed for the next cycle. (N44)

Definition: Retrospective is inspecting process health. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the formal team meeting to review the past sprint, identify process failures, and plan systemic improvements. (N44)

Definition: Retrospective is distilling key learnings. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a structured post-mortem on a writing project to distill key learnings about the writing and research process.

Definition: Retrospective is analyzing the artistic workflow. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a Studio Critique (N76) focused on the efficiency, coherence, and principles of the creative process.

Definition: Retrospective is facilitated dialogue. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in a facilitated Council (N65) or dialogue session to reflect on collective actions and reaffirm shared agreements.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Retrospective. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Look back on a past event or period to evaluate what went well, what didn't, and how to improve in the future.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Retrospective. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Look back on a past event or period to evaluate what went well, what didn't, and how to improve in the future.

concepts.name: Revision
concepts.theory_application: Make changes to a work or plan based on feedback, new information, or further reflection.

variations.theory: Definition: Revision is implementing changes to the protocol. Procedural Link: The action is to implement changes to the protocol or apparatus to improve the scientific design.
Definition: Revision is rewriting code. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the act of rewriting code or updating design files based on the feedback received.

Definition: Revision is intellectual work of rewriting. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the intellectual work of rewriting and restructuring the argument based on peer and editorial feedback. (N36)
Definition: Revision is altering the art object. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the physical act of altering the art object or performing a different version of the score.
Definition: Revision is the adjustment of a policy. Procedural Link: The action is to engage in the adjustment of a policy or social contract based on an ethical audit.
Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Revision. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Make changes to a work or plan based on feedback, new information, or further reflection.
Definition: The universal structural principle of Revision. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Make changes to a work or plan based on feedback, new information, or further reflection.

concepts.name: Metacognition
concepts.scenario: A student realizing they studied the wrong way.
concepts.theory_application: Engage in 'thinking about thinking'—monitoring and regulating your own cognitive processes to improve learning and performance.

variations.theory: Definition: Metacognition consists of knowledge and regulation. Procedural Link: The action is to pause and ask: 'Do I actually understand this, or am I just recognizing the terms?'
Definition: Look down on your machine. Procedural Link: The action is to step out of the execution role and evaluate the design of the team/process itself.
variations.rubric: Evaluates the machine, not the output.

variations.theory: Definition: Reflexivity. Procedural Link: The action is to analyze how your own background and biases are shaping your interpretation of the text.
Definition: Separating generation from evaluation. Procedural Link: The action is to notice the voice of the critic and consciously choose whether to listen to it or dismiss it.
Definition: The Witness Consciousness. Procedural Link: The action is to observe one's own emotional reaction to a trigger without acting on it.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Metacognition. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Engage in 'thinking about thinking'—monitoring and regulating your own cognitive processes to improve learning and performance.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Metacognition. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Engage in 'thinking about thinking'—monitoring and regulating your own cognitive processes to improve learning and performance.

concepts.name: Cognitive Distortion
concepts.scenario: Receiving critical feedback and feeling like a failure.
concepts.theory_application: Identify irrational or exaggerated thought patterns (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing thinking) that skew the interpretation of feedback.

variations.theory: Definition: CBT identifies automatic negative thoughts. Procedural Link: The action is to identify 'All-or-Nothing' thinking ('This data point is an outlier, so the whole experiment is ruined').
Definition: Loss Aversion. Procedural Link: The action is to identify where the fear of losing a feature is irrationally outweighing the gain of a new direction.
Definition: Fallacies. Procedural Link: The action is to identify 'Ad Hominem' or 'Straw Man' distortions in one's own reaction to a critique.
Definition: Discounting the Positive. Procedural Link: The action is to notice the tendency to ignore praise and fixate on the one negative comment.
Definition: Internalized oppression. Procedural Link: The action is to identify where societal narratives are distorting the self-assessment of capability.

Definition: Facilitating the learning and transfer of Cognitive Distortion. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Identify irrational or exaggerated thought patterns (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing thinking) that skew the interpretation of feedback.

Definition: The universal structural principle of Cognitive Distortion. Procedural Link: Apply this concept to: Identify irrational or exaggerated thought patterns (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing thinking) that skew the interpretation of feedback.

concepts.name: Root Cause
concepts.theory_application: Trace a symptom back to its fundamental origin to prevent recurrence, rather than just treating the surface issue.

variations.theory: Definition: Patient Zero. Procedural Link: The action is to trace the chain of transmission back to the single source of the outbreak.
Definition: 5 Whys. Procedural Link: The action is to ask 'Why?' five times until the answer is a process failure, not a human error.
variations.rubric: Identifies process failure, not human error.

variations.theory: Definition: Base and Superstructure. Procedural Link: The action is to trace a cultural symptom (superstructure) back to its economic root (base).
Definition: Fundamental Flaw. Procedural Link: The action is to trace a messy drawing back to a poor initial gesture or posture.
Definition: Structural Violence. Procedural Link: The action is to trace an individual tragedy back to a policy decision.
